review: Everything worked great for several weeks, but recently one of the Chromecasts keeps losing connection to our WiFi (i.e. our Android smartphones and Chrome browsers can no longer find the Chromecast).  Rebooting the Chromecast (by removing the USB power) fixes things for a short while (30 mins or so), and then the Chromecast is not visible on the network again.  Nothing has changed on the network (same WiFi, access points etc), and all our laptops and phones work fine.  Another Chromecast (we have 3) worked fine for a few hours, and then would only put out a black and white picture (even after factory reset and reboots).  So, a great idea when it works, but the quality of these units is clearly sub-par and there are some significant kinks to be worked out.Update: 2014-11-26:  2 out of 3 of these devices continue to be worthless.  Reset to factory defaults, reboot, log back in to WiFi - everything works great for an hour, but then they lose connection, and the Android Chomecast App or Desktop Chrome plugins cant find them again . 1 of the 3 works perfectly.  A pretty pathetic quality score there.  While the AppleTVs are more expensive, and dont have quite the potential (at this time) that the Chromecast does, they do at least *work* when you need them, which counts for a lot. Dropped rating to 1/5
author: The Wizard of Oz

review: I like the form factor of this dongle. It's small and hides neatly behind the TV. Setup was easy and took less than 5 minutes. During the setup I noticed the first flaw: Chromecast does not support 5Ghz Wifi routers. That's a problem since in my building there are do many Wifi networks that the performance on my 2.4Ghz wifi is extremely poor. Not good for streaming. The second flaw is the resolution: on my full HD TV it looked pixely and I seemed to get 720p only. Colors were off for my taste. I tried Netflix, Hulu plus and YouTube on my iPad and I could without any problem hand a stream over to Chromecast and control streaming from the app. If you have a smart TV already you will notice that handing over streams for Netflix and YouTube you can do already without the Chromecast and unlike with streaming via Chromecast, you do not loose the ability to control streaming with your TV remote control. So then I tried casting Chrome tabs to Chromecast. You need to install a plugin and fiddle with Firewall permissions since the Chromecast needs to be able to establish a connection to Chrome. When I castes a tab with a steam, I noticed a lag and a jitter. And this feature is marked as beta and crashes all the time. There is also an option to mirror the entire screen. Worked OK and us maybe an option when you wanna give a presentation. But don't expect you can watch a stream with this.All in all I am disappointed and decided to return it. The lack of 5ghz wifi is a deal breaker. And if you already have a smart TV, the Chromecast does not give much added value.

review: I purchased this a few weeks ago on impulse after reading a lot of hype on how great this device is.  Had I done the research I typically do before making an electronics purchase, I would have saved about an hour of setup and trying to figure out how to share videos I'd taken on my phone.  Instead, based on the description I read, I was led to believe that Google came out with a media player that gives you the ability to stream photos and music from your phone or computer. "Genius!" I thought.  I bought it believing it would be much easier than having to connect my phone to the TV if I want to show off my video footage on a larger screen for house guests!  Nope.  Apparently, Chromecast only allows a certain number of applications to work with the device.  Tonight, after actually doing the extensive research I should have done initially, I found that it is possible to stream local videos IF I upload them to youtube first.  But that, to me, is a PITA.  To add insult to injury, I found that there was a way to stream local media through an app called Allcast, but Google blocked it from streaming to Chromecast.With Chromecast's restrictions paired with the limited application support, I can't see any good reason to use this for anybody who has a WDTV Live, Roku or any other streaming device.  Because fortunately, Allcast (and likely other apps) does stream local media to these devices without having to jump through a bunch of Google's hoops, rendering the Chromecast useless and a waste of money.
